ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about anthropology, mobile societies, and more importantly, about New Haven and how to apply theoretical things we talk about in class to my own life right now, right here and how to think about life in general. This was a wonderful class.
overview of the concept of mobility; sociological investigation; effective forms of interaction with a community

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Honeychurch was the most important component of this course. His warmth, genuine concern about the world, justice, equality, curiosity about everything, inclusivity, all these things really made the course the most wonderful course I've ever taken at Yale. He imparted a lot of values to us, and he didn't just preach them, he lived by the same values.
strength;: professor honeychurch, constant field trips, amazing speakers, great material

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Professor Honeychurch was the most important component of this course. His warmth, genuine concern about the world, justice, equality, curiosity about everything, inclusivity, all these things really made the course the most wonderful course I've ever taken at Yale. He imparted a lot of values to us, and he didn't just preach them, he lived by the same values.
yes, intorduced a whole new frame of thinking about human society
